description.narrative:
De internationella organisationerna Mercy Corps och Adventist Development and Relief Agency (ADRA) har ansökt om stöd från Sida om 93 MSEK för att tillsammans genomföra projektet "Strenghtening Agricultural Markets and Food Security (SAFE)" i Sudan under perioden 2019-2022. Av dessa organisationer är Mercy Corps Sidas avtalspart.
Insatsen syftar till att öka jordbruksproduktionen genom miljömässigt hållbart jordbruk och bättre fungerande jordbruksmarknader. Insatsen kommer att fokusera på tre respektive fyra områden i delstaterna Blå Nilen och Södra Kordofan.
Insatsen bygger till stor del på en marknadssystemansats (MSD) med ett adaptivt arbetssätt vilket innebär att projektets aktiviteter kan komma att förändras under aktivitetsperioden. En MSD-ansats syftar till att adressera grundorsaker till att marknader som är av vikt för människor som lever i fattigdom inte tillräckligt gagnar dessa grupper, vilket på sikt ska resultera i långsiktiga förändringar som kan skalas upp till att nå många. Detta kan också innebära att det tar längre tid att se konkreta resultat men att dessa är uthålliga när de väl uppnås. Ansatsen kommer däför innebära att Sida behöver ta ställning till förändringar i programmet och vara en aktiv dialogpart.
Det övergripande målet med insatsen är förbättrad livsmedelsförsörjning för 20 000 småbrukande bondehushåll, motsvarande 120 000 personer, genom ökat och jämställt marknadstillträde och ökad jordbrukproduktion. Målet förväntas uppnås genom att uppfylla följande förväntade resultat:
1. Manliga och kvinnliga småbrukande bönder har ökad och mer klimatresilient produktion 2. Manliga och kvinnliga småbrukande bönder ökar tillämpningen av hållbar naturresursanvändning 3. Manliga och kvinnliga småbrukande bönder har förbättrade marknadskopplingar (tillgång till finansiering och insatsvaror för jordbruket) 4. Ökad jämställdhet mellan män, kvinnor, pojkar och flickor och mer egenmakt till kvinnor och flickor verksamma inom marknader av vikt för det småskaliga jordbruket.
Insatsens budget är 93,25 MSEK varav 250 000 SEK är avsatta för systemrevision under insatsens andra år och upphandlad av Sida.

The international organisations Mercy Corps and Adventist Development and Relief Agency (ADRA) have applied to Sida for funding of 93 million SEK to carry out "Strenghtening Agricultural Markets and Food Security (SAFE)" in Sudan for the period 2019-2022. The intervention will be carried out by a consortia of Mercy Corps and ADRA, where the former is the agreement partner to Sida.
The intervetion aims at improving agricultural production through environmentally sustainable farming and improved marketing systems. The geographical areas chosen are Blue Nile (BNS) and South Kordofan (SKS) states in Sudan targeting 3 localities and 4 localities in BNS and SKS respectively.
The intervention is to a large extent based on a Market Systems Approach (MSD) applying adaptive management, which means that changes of project activities might take place during the project period. A MSD approach aims to address underlying causes of poor perfomance in specific markets that matter to people living in poverty, resulting in scaleable long-term changes. This may also mean that it takes longer to see concrete results, but that these should be sustainable once they are achieved. The approach will therefore mean that Sida needs to accept changes in the programme and be an active dialogue partner.
The common rationale is to address the underlying causes of poor performance in specific markets that matter to poor people, producing scaleable long-term change.
The overall goal of the programme is improved food security for 20,000 male and female smallholder farmer households through enhanced gender equitable market access and agricultural production To achieve the project goal, the project has the following objectivies:
1. Male and female smallholder farmers have increased and more climate resilient yields 2. Male and female smallholder farmers increase sustainable natural resources management practices 3. Male and female smallholder farmers have improved market linkages (access to finance and agricultural inputs) 4. Increased equality between men, women, boys and girls and increased empowerment of women and girls in smallholder agricultural market systems.
The intervention's total budget is 93,25 million SEK, out of which 0.25 million SEK is allocated for an internal management and control review during the second year of the intervention which would be procured by Sida.

The main goal of the “Strengthening Agriculture Market and Food Security” SAFE project is to improve the food security for 20,000 male and female smallholder farmer households across South Kordofan and Blue Nile states, through enhanced gender equitable market access and agricultural production resilience. The project is guided by a Market Systems Development (MSD) and resilience approaches, to sustain food security gains despite the complex risk environment in which smallholder farmers are exposed to. The project is centred around four key objectives: Objective 1: Male and female smallholder farmers have increased and more climate resilient agricultural yields Objective 2: Male and female smallholder farmers increase sustainable natural resource management practices Objective 3: Male and female smallholder farmers have improved market linkages (access to finance and agricultural inputs) Objective 4: Increased equality between men, women, boys and girls and increased empowerment of women and girls in smallholder agricultural market systems. The Theory of Change is stated as: IF male and female smallholder farmers have improved, climate-adapted agricultural skills, gender equitable access to risk-informed inputs and financial services, and linkages to end-markets and IF an enabling market system is strengthened to create an inclusive, gender -equitable environment that accounts for key conflict, economic and climate/environment risks, THEN households will have improved and more sustainable production levels, improving their household food security, income and resilience to future shocks and stresses. To reach the objectives, training, material inputs and supporting functions are proposed. The core activities will be carried out through three groups which foreseeably will overlap: Community Groups who will work with Community Action Planning (CAP) Farmer School Groups, who will receive needed training in more advanced agricultural techniques and access to climate information, and with Cooperatives, which will organise groups of farmers for the more sustainable purchasing of agricultural inputs, work to minimize post harvest loss and assist in timely selling of excess crops. Some of these Farmer and Cooperative groups already exist, but many need to be revived or restored. It is expected that the community will be the basis for the infrastructure activities, conflict resolution, and they have often been found to be the driving force behind the local developments. The Farmer Schools will be where most of the training will take place and where the connection to the state agricultural extension officers occurs. Cooperatives will work to better coordinate and leverage the farmers ability to purchase agricultural inputs as well as to sell surplus production at better rates, and assist in obtaining financial services to the smallholder farmers. Supporting functions will be especially in the market systems development where private sector will be encouraged to provide access to agricultural inputs and to purchase the surplus crops. Available financial services is another support function which the partners have identified as critical to the farmers and communities ability to further develop. Village Savings and Loans (VSLA) are one proposed means of providing financial services to smallholder farmers, but other financing initiatives have been identified and will be explored and developed.

title.narrative: Grant agreement between Sida and Mercycorps

description.narrative: Embassy of Khartoum is in the process of reviewing the SAFE program’s inception report package. As this is being reviewed, Mercy Corps has requested Embassy of Khartoum to approve the initiation of time-critical activities. Most of the SAFE’s program activities (access to inputs, output markets, PHH materials, agriculture extension for smallholder farmers) are centered around private sector partnerships. However, the process of developing partnerships is time-consuming and laborious and, at best can take a couple of months. It takes additional time for the partners to mobilize their portion of the financial contribution as well as set up business structures on the ground to be able to work with the smallholder farmers. With the onset of rains expected in less than 2 months, and to allow the program to follow the MSD approach, the partnership development process needs to start right away. Embassy of Khartoum therfor approves Mercy Corps requests to allow them use $ 37,370, expected to be spent by end of June 2020, for time critical activties.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
